Literature Review: Coughing is a vital protective reflex that helps clear the airways of irritants and pathogens. However, it can also be a significant symptom of respiratory infections and a means of disease transmission. This literature review explores the neurophysiology of cough, its induction by respiratory pathogens and inflammation, and its role in disease transmission.The neurophysiology of cough involves a complex interplay between sensory neurons, brainstem circuits, and efferent pathways. Canning et al. (2014) describe how vagal afferent nerves, particularly those expressing transient receptor potential (TRP) channels, play a crucial role in detecting irritants and initiating the cough reflex. These sensory neurons project to the nucleus tractus solitarius in the brainstem, where the cough neural network is organized. The integration of sensory inputs and the generation of the cough motor pattern involve multiple brainstem regions, as elucidated by Mazzone and Undem (2016).Respiratory pathogens can induce coughing through various mechanisms. Viral infections, such as those caused by influenza or respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), can directly activate sensory neurons or induce the release of inflammatory mediators that stimulate cough receptors. Zaccone et al. (2016) demonstrated that RSV infection increases the excitability of vagal bronchopulmonary sensory neurons, leading to enhanced cough sensitivity. Similarly, bacterial pathogens like Bordetella pertussis produce toxins that can directly stimulate sensory nerves or modulate inflammatory responses to induce coughing.Inflammation plays a significant role in cough induction during respiratory infections. Grace et al. (2013) showed that inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins, bradykinin, and nerve growth factor can sensitize or directly activate airway sensory nerves. This heightened sensitivity can lead to an exaggerated cough response to otherwise innocuous stimuli, a phenomenon known as cough hypersensitivity syndrome. Chronic respiratory conditions like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are characterized by persistent airway inflammation, which contributes to chronic cough in these patients.The role of neurogenic inflammation in cough has gained increasing attention. Nassini et al. (2010) described how the activation of TRP channels on sensory nerves can lead to the release of neuropeptides, causing neurogenic inflammation and further amplifying the cough response. This mechanism may explain the persistence of cough even after the resolution of the initial infection or irritant exposure.Cough-mediated disease transmission is a critical aspect of respiratory infection epidemiology. Lindsley et al. (2012) analyzed the aerosols generated by coughing and found that they contain a significant number of potentially infectious particles. The size distribution of these particles determines how long they remain airborne and how deeply they can penetrate the respiratory tract of susceptible individuals. Larger droplets tend to settle quickly, while smaller aerosols can remain suspended for extended periods, potentially increasing the risk of airborne transmission.The efficiency of cough-mediated transmission varies among different pathogens. Yan et al. (2018) conducted a comprehensive study on influenza transmission and found that coughing significantly increased the amount of viral RNA in exhaled breath aerosols. This finding highlights the importance of cough in the spread of influenza and potentially other respiratory viruses.Interestingly, some pathogens have evolved mechanisms to exploit the cough reflex for their transmission. The classic example is Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough. Melvin et al. (2014) described how pertussis toxin and other virulence factors produced by B. pertussis not only induce severe coughing episodes but also modulate the host immune response to prolong the infection and increase the opportunity for transmission.Understanding the link between cough and disease transmission has important implications for public health interventions. Leung et al. (2020) demonstrated the effectiveness of face masks in reducing the emission of influenza virus and human coronaviruses in respiratory droplets and aerosols from individuals with acute respiratory infections. This finding underscores the importance of non-pharmaceutical interventions in controlling the spread of respiratory infections.In conclusion, the intricate relationship between infectious and inflammatory pathways and cough highlights the complex nature of this protective reflex. While cough serves as a crucial defense mechanism, it can also be exploited by pathogens for transmission. Further research into the neurophysiology of cough, its modulation by pathogens and inflammation, and its role in disease transmission will be essential for developing more effective strategies to manage respiratory infections and limit their spread.
